title: The Forgotten Affairs of Youth
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: He  was puzzled. There  was nothing  to see in Blackfriars Street, he thought; was there anything there? Bannerman's Bar at the bottom and a place that sold folk instruments and Scottish fiddle music.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " Just listen to this about Blackfriars Street, which used to be called Friars Wynd," I remember his exclaiming  one evening, as a prelude to his reading the following  passage :

title: The Forgotten Affairs of Youth
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: 'Oh. Well, we're almost at Blackfriars Street. You did want to walk up it, didn't you?'

title: The Forgotten Affairs of Youth
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: And . . . there was nothing else, he thought, unless one  counted  the  tenement  flats. It made for, of course, an attractive enough stroll, but there were plenty of places more interesting than Blackfriars Street, and if Isabel were prepared to be imaginative, a much better walk could be concocted.

title: The Forgotten Affairs of Youth
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: I always remember that. Number twenty-four Blackfriars Street.'

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " That was the night Darnley was blown up," he went on; "we must find Blackfriars Street and Todrick' s Close to-morrow; they can't be far from the palace. I wish we knew more about those streets near

title: The Forgotten Affairs of Youth
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Catherine Succoth told me about it. She said it was number twenty-four Blackfriars Street.'
